children.subject: lol looks like this is also another way to monitor air currents.

history.content:
Hi all, 
Among the two possible predicted path, our balloon chose to make a rapid left turn and move North, while the chasing balloon (W6MRR-22) ended up on a constant trajectory towards North Africa. 
Here’s the link to the tracking of the balloons: https://aprs.fi/#!mt=roadmap&z=8&call=a%2FNU6XB-14%2Ca%2FW6MRR-22&timerange=604800&tail=604800
Our balloon travelled about 1600miles overnight on a North-east trajectory, and woke up this morning just north west of the Azores Islands in the mid-Atlantic. Just to illustrate how far and fast it is traveling you will notice that yesterday the balloon went to sleep at a latitude of 31 (south-Georgia , south of Tijuana equivalent). It woke up this morning at a latitude of 42 (Boston, MA). At the end of the day it went to sleep at a latitude of 48! (New Foundland). Since we are getting close to the winter solstice, it gets dark quickly in these areas, so days are very short. 
The prediction for our balloon is that it will go over Iceland, enter Norway from the north, then Sweden, Finland, Estonia where it is predicted to be 24 hours from now. Attached is the prediction. 
Now, most of you do not have radios, nor access to radios. As it turns out, there are many amateur radio operators who are running web servers that allow you to listen to various frequency bands received by their stations. You can effectively control the radios and demodulate and listen to different signals, for voice as well as digital. 
This is a link to a map of many receivers you can tune to: https://www.receiverbook.de/map?type=openwebrx . You will have to use a chrome browser to make this work. Feel free to check some of these out!
If you want to listen to a WSPR signal in Europe, here’s a link to a station in the Netherlands:

During the day (in Europe) listen to: http://kiwisdr.ddns.net:8074/#freq=14095600,mod=usb,secondary_mod=wspr,sql=-150

During the night (in Europe) listen to : http://kiwisdr.ddns.net:8074/#freq=7038600,mod=usb,secondary_mod=wspr,sql=-150
If you wait about 5 minutes, you should be able to see decodes. 
They have a format of : UTC, dB, DT, Freq, and Message. 
UTC is the time in Coordinated Universal Time
dB is the signal to noise ratio (SNR)  the signal was received at.  The higher it is, the stronger the signal is. Just to give an illustration, the SNR of -12db is barely audible. WSPR can dig signals out of the noise as low as -31dB, which is about a 100 times weaker. 
DT is the delay of the signal, measured in seconds. WSPR transmission are synchronized to the an even minute and all start at the same time. 
Freq: is the frequency in Hz
Message has the format of:  Callsign, position, power.    Callsign is the callsign of the beacon station. The position is described by two letters and two numbers, which represent a grid square on the earth (here’s one for the US: https://w9dup.org/grid_squares.html), and the power is the transmitted power of the station in dbm units. 
For example: 

UTC dB DT Freq Message
162400 -26 1.4 14097026 VE3KCL IM40 10
VE3KCL is the callsign of David H Beverstein, from Toronto Canada (https://www.qrz.com/lookup need a free account)
IM40 is a square over the Atlantic west of the coast of Morocco (this is also a balloon!)  (grid square locator link: https://www.levinecentral.com/ham/grid_square.php)
10 means 10dbm, which is also 10 milliwatts 
More tomorrow…. Hopefully. 
— Miki
history.subject: EECS Balloon, day 6(!) winter is coming....
